objectives: Understand the concept of tense as it relates to the timing of an action.
Identify the three main categories of tenses: Past, Present, and Future. [1, 4]
Learn the 12 types of tenses and their specific uses with detailed examples.
Practice forming positive, negative, and question sentences for all 12 tenses.

sections.text: In English grammar, a tense is a form a verb takes to show the time an action happened. [4] Tenses are fundamental because they provide context, helping us understand whether an event occurred in the past, is happening in the present, or will happen in the future. [1] Mastering the 12 tenses allows for precise and clear communication, enabling you to construct complex and accurate sentences. [1, 28] The three main categories of tenses are Past, Present, and Future, which are further divided into four aspects: Simple, Continuous (or Progressive), Perfect, and Perfect Continuous. [28]

examples.label: Past: I walked home.
examples.value: This action was completed in the past.

examples.label: Present: I walk home.
examples.value: This is a habitual action in the present.

examples.label: Future: I will walk home.
examples.value: This action will happen in the future.

table.title: The Three Main Tense Categories
rows: Describes actions happening now or that happen regularly. [7, 13]
Describes actions that have already happened. [1, 13]
Describes actions that have not yet happened but are expected to. [1, 2, 13]

sections.text: The Simple Present Tense is used for habits, routines, general truths, and facts. [18, 21, 23] For subjects 'I', 'you', 'we', and 'they', the base form of the verb is used. For 'he', 'she', and 'it', an '-s' or '-es' is added to the verb.

examples.label: I drink coffee every morning.
examples.value: This describes a daily habit.

examples.label: The Earth revolves around the Sun. [21]
examples.value: This is a universal fact.

examples.label: He works at the hospital.
examples.value: This describes a regular situation.

examples.label: The train arrives at 7 PM. [21]
examples.value: This refers to a fixed schedule.

usage_examples: She plays the piano beautifully.
We visit our grandparents on weekends.
Water boils at 100 degrees Celsius.
They live in London.
The store opens at 9 AM.

sections.text: The Present Continuous (or Progressive) Tense is used to describe an action that is happening right now, at this very moment. [5, 46] It is also used for temporary actions and definite future plans. [39, 44] It is formed with the verb 'to be' (am, is, are) and the verb's present participle (-ing form). [5]

examples.label: I am studying for my exam.
examples.value: This action is happening right now. [27]

examples.label: They are playing football in the park.
examples.value: This describes an ongoing activity.

examples.label: She is working from home this week.
examples.value: This is a temporary situation. [44]

examples.label: We are meeting our friends tonight. [39]
examples.value: This is a fixed plan for the near future.

usage_examples: The chef is cooking a delicious meal.
He is constantly checking his phone.
Are you listening to me?
I am not working tomorrow.
More and more people are using social media. [39]

sections.text: The Present Perfect Tense is used to describe an action that happened at an unspecified time in the past but has relevance to the present. [4, 31, 42] It can also describe an action that started in the past and continues to the present. It is formed using 'have' or 'has' and the past participle (V3) of the verb. [29]

examples.label: I have finished my homework.
examples.value: The action is complete, and the result (finished homework) is relevant now. [17]

examples.label: She has lived in this city for ten years.
examples.value: The action started in the past and is still ongoing.

examples.label: They have visited Paris twice.
examples.value: This describes a life experience without a specific time. [31]

examples.label: He has just left. [17]
examples.value: This refers to a very recent past action.

usage_examples: Have you ever eaten sushi?
We haven't seen that movie yet.
The company has grown significantly.
I've lost my keys, so I can't open the door.
She has worked here since 2015.

table.title: Present Perfect Tense Structures
rows: They have not completed the project.

sections.text: The Present Perfect Continuous Tense is used to emphasize the duration of an action that started in the past and is still continuing. [7] It can also describe an action that has recently finished and has a result in the present. It is formed using 'has/have been' and the present participle (-ing form) of the verb.

examples.label: I have been waiting for two hours.
examples.value: This emphasizes the duration of the waiting period, which continues to the present.

examples.label: She has been studying since morning. [12]
examples.value: This shows an action that began in the morning and is still in progress.

examples.label: It has been raining all day.
examples.value: This emphasizes the continuous nature of the rain over a period of time.

examples.label: Your eyes are red because you have been crying.
examples.value: The action of crying has just finished, and the result is visible now.

usage_examples: They have been building that bridge for months.
How long have you been learning English?
He is tired because he has been working out.
We have been living here since 2010.
She hasn't been feeling well lately.

sections.text: The Simple Past Tense is used to describe completed actions that happened at a specific point in the past. [7, 13] Regular verbs typically end in '-ed', while irregular verbs have unique past tense forms. [47]

examples.label: I visited my grandparents last week.
examples.value: The action was completed at a specific time in the past ('last week').

examples.label: She finished her work an hour ago.
examples.value: This describes a past action with a definite end time.

examples.label: They went to the cinema yesterday.
examples.value: 'Went' is the irregular past form of 'go'.

examples.label: He bought a new car last month. [13]
examples.value: The action of buying is finished and occurred in the past.

usage_examples: We played football after school.
Did you see the movie on TV last night?
The Titanic sank in 1912.
He didn't come to the party.
I wrote a letter to my friend.

table.title: Simple Past Tense Structures
rows: He did not write a letter. [48]

sections.text: The Past Continuous Tense describes an ongoing action in the past, often when another, shorter action interrupted it. [19, 25, 40] It is also used to describe two actions happening at the same time in the past. [10, 25] It is formed with 'was' or 'were' and the verb's present participle (-ing form). [19]

examples.label: I was watching TV when the phone rang. [35]
examples.value: The longer action ('watching TV') was interrupted by a shorter action ('rang').

examples.label: She was cooking while he was reading a book.
examples.value: Two parallel actions were happening simultaneously in the past. [40]

examples.label: They were playing in the garden all evening.
examples.value: This emphasizes the duration of an ongoing past action.

examples.label: At 8 PM last night, I was studying.
examples.value: This describes an action in progress at a specific time in the past. [40]

usage_examples: What were you doing when the storm started?
He was working as a teacher back then.
It was raining heavily yesterday.
The children were laughing and shouting.
She was always complaining about her job. [35]

sections.text: The Past Perfect Tense is used to describe an action that was completed before another action in the past. [6, 26, 43] It is often called the "past of the past." It is formed using 'had' and the past participle (V3) of the verb. [6, 41]

examples.label: The train had left when I arrived at the station.
examples.value: First action: the train left. Second action: I arrived. The first action is in the past perfect.

examples.label: She had finished her homework before she went to play.
examples.value: This clearly shows the sequence of two past events.

examples.label: By the time he was 25, he had started his own company.
examples.value: The action of starting a company happened before he turned 25.

examples.label: I couldn't get in because I had lost my keys. [20]
examples.value: The action of losing the keys happened before the action of trying to get in.

usage_examples: They had never seen such a beautiful sunset before.
Had you studied French before you moved to Paris?
He hadn't eaten all day, so he was very hungry.
After he had done his chores, he watched a movie.
We had already booked the tickets.

sections.text: The Past Perfect Continuous Tense is used to emphasize the duration of an action that was in progress before another action took place in the past. [3, 9, 33] It shows how long something had been happening. It is formed using 'had been' and the present participle (-ing form). [3, 11]

examples.label: He had been working for three hours when he finally took a break.
examples.value: This emphasizes the duration ('for three hours') of the first action before the second one occurred.

examples.label: They had been waiting for a long time before the bus arrived. [37]
examples.value: This focuses on the continuous act of waiting before another past event.

examples.label: She was tired because she had been running.
examples.value: This shows the cause (running for a duration) of a past state (being tired). [11]

examples.label: How long had you been studying before you passed the exam? [37]
examples.value: This asks about the duration of a past activity.

usage_examples: I had been living in that city for five years before I moved.
The ground was wet because it had been raining.
He had been feeling unwell for weeks before he went to the doctor.
They hadn't been getting along for a while.
We had been driving for hours when the car broke down.

sections.text: The Simple Future Tense is used to talk about actions or events that will happen in the future. [14, 22] It is often used for predictions, spontaneous decisions, or promises. It is most commonly formed using 'will' or 'be going to' followed by the base form of the verb. [2, 16]

examples.label: I will call you tomorrow.
examples.value: This is a promise or a planned future action. [14]

examples.label: She is going to study medicine.
examples.value: This indicates a pre-decided plan or intention. [22]

examples.label: It will probably rain later.
examples.value: This is a prediction about the future.

examples.label: I think I will have the soup.
examples.value: This is a spontaneous decision made at the moment of speaking.

usage_examples: They will arrive at 10 AM.
He won't be late.
Are you going to attend the meeting? [14]
We will help you with your project.
The sun will rise at 6 AM.

table.title: Simple Future Tense Structures
rows: Subject + will + V1 / Subject + am/is/are + going to + V1
Subject + will + not + V1 / Subject + am/is/are + not + going to + V1
Will + Subject + V1? / Am/Is/Are + Subject + going to + V1?

sections.text: The Future Continuous Tense describes an ongoing action that will be in progress at a specific time in the future. [15, 30] It is formed using 'will be' and the present participle (-ing form). [34]

examples.label: This time tomorrow, I will be flying to Paris. [15]
examples.value: This describes an action that will be in progress at a specific future moment.

examples.label: Don't call me at 9 PM, I will be sleeping then. [36]
examples.value: This indicates an ongoing action at a future point.

examples.label: They will be watching a movie when we arrive.
examples.value: This describes a longer, ongoing future action that will be interrupted by a shorter one.

examples.label: She will be giving a presentation at this time next week. [15]
examples.value: This refers to a planned, ongoing event in the future.

usage_examples: He will be working late tonight. [15]
Will you be joining us for dinner? [15]
I won't be attending the conference next month.
This evening, we will be celebrating his birthday.
What will you be doing in ten years?

table.title: Future Continuous Tense Structures
rows: She will be waiting for us. [12]
She will not be waiting for us.
Will she be waiting for us?

sections.text: The Future Perfect Tense is used to describe an action that will be completed before a specific time or another event in the future. [7, 49] It is formed using 'will have' and the past participle (V3) of the verb.

examples.label: By 8 PM, I will have finished my dinner.
examples.value: The action of finishing dinner will be complete before the future time of 8 PM.

examples.label: She will have graduated by next year.
examples.value: The action of graduating will be complete before the point 'next year'.

examples.label: By the time you arrive, we will have already left.
examples.value: The action of leaving will be complete before the future event of your arrival.

examples.label: In three years, they will have built the new bridge.
examples.value: This describes a completed action at a point in the future.

usage_examples: Will you have completed the report by the deadline?
He won't have saved enough money by then.
By the end of this month, I will have worked here for five years.
They will have painted the house before they move in.
The movie will have ended by 10 o'clock.

table.title: Future Perfect Tense Structures
rows: They will have completed the task. [12]
They will not have completed the task.
Will they have completed the task?

sections.text: The Future Perfect Continuous Tense is used to emphasize the duration of an action that will be in progress up to a certain point in the future. [7] It shows how long an action will have been happening. It is formed using 'will have been' and the present participle (-ing form).

examples.label: By next year, I will have been working here for ten years.
examples.value: This emphasizes the ten-year duration of the action up to a future point ('next year').

examples.label: In an hour, she will have been studying for the entire afternoon.
examples.value: This focuses on the length of the continuous action of studying.

examples.label: When he turns 30, he will have been playing the piano for 25 years.
examples.value: This highlights the duration of the activity up to a future milestone.

examples.label: By the time you get here, we will have been waiting for two hours.
examples.value: This emphasizes the length of the waiting period before a future event.

usage_examples: How long will you have been driving by 6 PM?
They will have been traveling for a month by the time they return.
He won't have been sleeping for long when his alarm rings.
In 2030, we will have been living in this house for two decades.
By midnight, the band will have been playing for four hours.

table.title: Future Perfect Continuous Tense Structures
rows: I will have been traveling for 5 hours. [12]
Subject + will + not + have + been + V1-ing
I will not have been traveling for 5 hours.
Will you have been traveling for 5 hours?
